newsitem.title: GERMANY: German retail coffee price rise needed - Dallmayr.
newsitem.headline: German retail coffee price rise needed - Dallmayr.

text.p: German premium coffee roaster Alois Dallmayr Kaffee oHG said it wished for higher retail prices in a fiercely competitive market but it questioned the likelihood of success.
"A price rise would be more than due but the question is can it be implemented in the current competitive climate," a statement with company figures for 1996 said.
Dallmayr said average German retail prices had fallen to 6.70 marks per kg in 1996 from 7.23 marks, but roasters' raw materials bills had increased by 15 percent.
Competitive pressures last month forced loss-making Bremen roaster Eduscho GmbH & Co KG to accept a purchase bid by competitor Tchibo Frisch Roest-Kaffee GmbH, pending cartel authority approval.
The two joint companies would battle for market leadership with Kraft Jacobs Suchard, which in October had a 30.7 percent volume market share.
Dallmayr said it raised its own market share to eight percent in 1996 from 7.2 percent in 1995, boosted by sales in eastern Germany.
Sales volumes were 38,000 tonnes of roasted coffee (34,000 tonnes in 1995) and sales values 592 million marks (573 million).

Dallmayr usually buys 750,000 60-kg bags of green coffee each year, roughly one percent of projected world exports in the 1996/97 season, from a range of origins, but it gave Guatemala, Kenya and Ethiopia special mention.
